Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Quantifying Temporal Changes in Rockfall Magnitude-Frequencies for Well-Characterized Rockslopes Shaken by the 2018 Alaska Earthquake

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Earthquakes cause many hazards during shaking, but some of the hazards linger long after the seismic event is over. For example, heightened frequency of landslides and rockfalls commonly occur in the months - and even years - following an earthquake. This Rapid Response Research (RAPID) project seeks to capture perishable data from several rock slopes highly susceptible to rockfall that were affected by the recent earthquake in Anchorage. By doing this, we may compare the rate and frequency of rockfall occurrence to pre-earthquake levels in order to better understand how much rockfall activity increases following shaking, and how long it takes to return to pre-earthquake levels. This has implications for post-earthquake recovery and seismic resilience throughout much of the US and abroad.

Earthquakes often trigger significant rockfall activity in steep cliffs. The recent 2018 November 30th Alaska earthquake caused significant shaking (up to 0.4g) across the Anchorage region, resulting in numerous rockfalls, landslides, and lateral spreads. The combination of potentially large volumes, high velocities, long travel distances, and impact forces make the rockfall hazard significant. Based on observations from past events in New Zealand, it is believed that rockfall activity over at least the next several months will exceed "normal" baseline levels before decreasing. Nevertheless, as is often the case, the previous research does not have detailed baseline information prior to the event. This prior research begs three primary scientific questions: what is "baseline" rockfall activity? How does shaking translate to increased rockfall activity, magnitude, and frequency particularly in the heterogenous geologic conditions encountered in the rock slopes surrounding Anchorage? And lastly, how quickly does rockfall activity and magnitude return to baseline conditions? This project seeks to collect rockfall activity rates through repeat terrestrial laser scanning at well-characterized rockfall sites near Anchorage. Change detection will be performed and the rate of rockfall activity characterized in comparison to previous epochs and the serial data collected as part of this project. With existing baseline data not influenced by recent seismic activity, we will characterize and compare the activity rate following shaking. This investigation will provide fundamental knowledge about the process that dictates both the increase and decay in rockfall activity after seismic disturbance. The resulting knowledge will provide data needed to support and advance modern performance- and risk-based extreme event design methodologies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award funded data collection of repeat high-resolution, terrestrial lidar on rockslopes, which experienced significant shaking in the 2018 Anchorage Earthquake. The recent 2018 November 30th Alaska earthquake caused significant shaking (up to 0.4g) across the Anchorage region, resulting in numerous rockfalls, landslides, and lateral spreads. The combination of potentially large volumes, high velocities, long travel distances, and impact forces made rockfall hazard significant in this region. Based on observations from past events in New Zealand (Massey et al. 2014) it is believed that rockfall activity following a seismic event will exceed ?normal? baseline levels for some time before attenuating. However, to date, no active rockfall site has well-characterized data on rockfall activity prior to shaking, i.e. baseline levels, as a control for comparison.

During the timespan of this project, we performed four data collection visits to the site following the earthquake: April 9-10, 2019, May 9-10 2019, June 4-5 2019, and August 15-16 2019 (Figure 1). While this project focused primarily on supporting collection of perishable, high-resolution imagery and lidar data of these well-characterized rockslopes subject to shaking, preliminary analyses do show a modest increase in normalized rockfall activity rates in comparison to previous years. Generally, the largest rates of rockfall activity were observed during the spring thaw (between May and June 2019), but all measured rockfall activity was larger than pre-earthquake conditions. Analysis of data collected after the earthquake also shows an eventual decrease in rockfall activity, which is expected to attenuate back to ?normal? baseline levels eventually.  The collection of baseline data prior to the earthquake enabled direct comparison of pre- and post-seismic rockfall activity through change analysis of high-resolution, three-dimensional lidar digital terrain models. To the research team?s knowledge, it presents the first dataset where high-resolution lidar of rockslopes is available both before and after an earthquake event. These data provide a fundamental input for understanding the prolonged hazard and risk posed from rockfalls. Such data is critical for planning recovery efforts after major earthquakes. These data can also be used for calibration and validation of numerical models as well as design methodologies.  The data have been archived in the Natural Hazards Engineering Research Infrastructure (NHERI) designsafe.ci (DOI: 10.17603/ds2-jmfv-9171) so that they are available to others for further analysis. Most earthquake-related hazard analyses focus on the timespan of a seismic event as prolonged post-shaking data is often limited in scope and time.

 


Last Modified: 06/02/2020
Modified by: Ben A Leshchinsky

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: This award funded data collection of repeat high-resolution, terrestrial lidar on rockslopes, which experienced significant shaking in the 2018 Anchorage Earthquake. The recent 2018 November 30th Alaska earthquake caused significant shaking (up to 0.4g) across the Anchorage region, resulting in numerous rockfalls, landslides, and lateral spreads. The combination of potentially large volumes, high velocities, long travel distances, and impact forces made rockfall hazard significant in this region. Based on observations from past events in New Zealand (Massey et al. 2014) it is believed that rockfall activity following a seismic event will exceed ?normal? baseline levels for some time before attenuating. However, to date, no active rockfall site has well-characterized data on rockfall activity prior to shaking, i.e. baseline levels, as a control for comparison. During the timespan of this project, we performed four data collection visits to the site following the earthquake: April 9-10, 2019, May 9-10 2019, June 4-5 2019, and August 15-16 2019 (Figure 1). While this project focused primarily on supporting collection of perishable, high-resolution imagery and lidar data of these well-characterized rockslopes subject to shaking, preliminary analyses do show a modest increase in normalized rockfall activity rates in comparison to previous years. Generally, the largest rates of rockfall activity were observed during the spring thaw (between May and June 2019), but all measured rockfall activity was larger than pre-earthquake conditions. The collection of baseline data prior to the earthquake enabled direct comparison of pre- and post-seismic rockfall activity through change analysis of high-resolution, three-dimensional lidar digital terrain models. To the research team?s knowledge, it presents the first dataset where high-resolution lidar of rockslopes is available both before and after an earthquake event. These data provide a fundamental input for understanding the prolonged hazard and risk posed from rockfalls. Such data is critical for planning recovery efforts after major earthquakes. These data can also be used for calibration and validation of numerical models as well as design methodologies. The data have been archived in the Natural Hazards Engineering Research Infrastructure (NHERI) designsafe.ci (DOI: 10.17603/ds2-jmfv-9171) so that they are available to others for further analysis. Most earthquake-related hazard analyses focus on the timespan of a seismic event as prolonged post-shaking data is often limited in scope and time.
